Question_1.Context: Vitamin K1 is important for bone and cardiovascular health and blood coagulation in the human body.
Question_1.Question: What is the major dietary form of vitamin K in most diets?
Question_1.Source: Vitamin K1 is a naturally occurring form of vitamin K in plants and the major dietary form of vitamin K in most diets.

Question_2.Context: Vitamin K1 is found in large quantities in photosynthetic tissues of dark green leafy vegetables.
Question_2.Question: Which function does vitamin K serve in plants?
Question_2.Source: Vitamin K1 is found in large quantities in photosynthetic tissues of dark green leafy vegetables since it functions as an electron acceptor during photosynthesis.

Question_3.Context: Vitamin K deficiency may cause failure in the regulation of vitamin K-dependent physiological processes.
Question_3.Question: What physiological processes may be affected by vitamin K deficiency?
Question_3.Source: Vitamin K deficiency may cause failure in the regulation of vitamin K-dependent physiological processes, including blood clotting.

Question_4.Context: Vitamin K1 is important for maintaining bone and cardiovascular health in elderly people.
Question_4.Question: What is the recommended average daily intake level of vitamin K for women according to the United States Institute of Medicine?
Question_4.Source: The recommended average daily intake level of vitamin K for women is 65 μg/day according to the United States Institute of Medicine.

Question_5.Context: Green leafy vegetables contribute more than one-half of total vitamin K1 intake.
Question_5.Question: Which green vegetables are mentioned to contain more than 300 μg of vitamin K1/100 g?
Question_5.Source: A few green vegetables, such as collards, spinach, and salad greens, contain more than 300 μg of vitamin K1/100 g.

Question_6.Context: Vitamin K1 is routinely measured using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC)–fluorescence detection.
Question_6.Question: What method overcame the problems of insufficient accuracy and precision in vitamin K1 measurement?
Question_6.Source: The problems have been overcome with the use of liquid chromatography/mass spectrometry (LC/MS), in particular, the stable isotope dilution method with LC/MS detection is considered the most accurate method.

Question_7.Context: The developed method for vitamin K1 analysis had a repeatability and reproducibility of less than 2% relative standard deviation.
Question_7.Question: What was used as an internal standard in the developed method for quantifying vitamin K1?
Question_7.Source: Vitamin K1-d7 was used as an internal standard in the developed method.

Question_8.Context: The method corrected for losses of target compounds during sample clean-up and compensated for the variation in ionization efficiency due to matrix interferences.
Question_8.Question: What was the main advantage of using isotopically labeled vitamin K1 as an internal standard?
Question_8.B: Corrected for losses during sample clean-up
Question_8.Source: As it uses isotopically labeled vitamin K1 as an internal standard, the method corrects for losses of target compounds during sample clean-up and compensates for the variation in ionization efficiency due to matrix interferences.

Question_9.Context: The method had a higher-order metrological quality as a reference method.
Question_9.Question: What was the chromatographic column employed for the separation of trans- and cis-vitamin K1 isomers?
Question_9.Source: A C30 column was employed for proper separation of trans- and cis-vitamin K1 isomers.

Question_10.Context: The method was validated by measuring gravimetrically fortified samples.
Question_10.Question: What was used to validate the performance parameters of the developed method?
Question_10.Source: The method was validated by measuring gravimetrically fortified samples.
